content:
You‚Äôll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

Jekyll requires blog post files to be named according to the following format:

YEAR-MONTH-DAY-title.MARKUP

Where YEAR is a four-digit number, MONTH and DAY are both two-digit numbers, and MARKUP is the file extension representing the format used in the file. After that, include the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

def print_hi(name)
  puts "Hi, #{name}"
end
print_hi('Tom')
#=> prints 'Hi, Tom' to STDOUT.

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyll‚Äôs GitHub repo. If you have questions, you can ask them on Jekyll Talk.

content: The Dalai Lama and the 1989 Nobel Peace Prize In 1989, the 14th Dalai Lama, Tenzin Gyatso, was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in recognition of his lifelong commitment to nonviolence, compassion, and the peaceful resolution of conflict. This historic moment not only honored his efforts for the Tibetan people but also cemented his place as one of the world‚Äôs most influential moral leaders. A Life Dedicated to Peace The Dalai Lama has long advocated for compassion, mindfulness, and coexistence. Even after the political upheaval in Tibet and his exile in 1959, he consistently promoted dialogue instead of confrontation. His approach, often described as a Middle Way, emphasized: Respect for all cultures and religions Nonviolent solutions to political conflict Human rights and freedom The idea that peace begins with inner transformation These values aligned deeply with the goals of the Nobel Peace Prize. Why He Was Awarded the Prize The Nobel Committee recognized him for: His unwavering commitment to nonviolence, even in the face of oppression. title: Static Site Generators vs Traditional CMS: Which Should You Choose?
excerpt: Choosing between a static site generator (SSG) and a traditional CMS can shape the future of your project. Here‚Äôs how they differ:
content:
Choosing between a static site generator (SSG) and a traditional CMS can shape the future of your project. Here‚Äôs how they differ:

Performance
SSGs like Jekyll create blazing-fast websites because pages are pre-built.

Security
Traditional CMS platforms can be vulnerable due to databases and admin panels. Static sites eliminate most of these risks.

Flexibility
CMS platforms offer more built-in features, while SSGs excel in developer control and customization.

Final Thoughts
If you value speed, security, and version control, an SSG is a strong choice. If you prefer non-technical editing, a CMS may be better.

title: Improving Developer Productivity in 2025
excerpt: Developer productivity continues to evolve quickly as new tools and workflows emerge. Here are a few ways to stay ahead:
content:
Developer productivity continues to evolve quickly as new tools and workflows emerge. Here are a few ways to stay ahead:

1. Automate the Boring Stuff
Automation is no longer optional. Scripts, CI pipelines, and editor macros save hours each week.

2. Use AI-Powered Assistants Wisely
Tools like code assistants and documentation generators reduce cognitive load and help you stay focused.

3. Reduce Context Switching
Batch similar tasks together and silence notifications while coding.

Conclusion
Productivity in 2025 is about optimizing the environment you code in. Small gains compound over time.
